_150CharacterPullQuoteFromBlurb: If there is a message about shared class struggles, it doesn’t seem pushed by the narrative. Rather, Joker’s fight against “The System” supersedes any other understanding of intersectional inequality.
copyEditedBlurb: Before Joker even came out, critics were concerned about the real-world ramifications of creating a folk hero out of Gotham City’s most infamous villain, giving him a rare spotlight as a protagonist. The film tries for a more sympathetic rendition of the man behind the clown makeup and attempts to indict the social systems that fail him, but ultimately the few interesting ideas about class or mental health in Joker are abandoned to adhere exclusively to Arthur Fleck’s individual experience as a working class white man. The film frames Arthur’s declining mental health as a symptom of the lack of economic resources and social safety nets for the disabled working class — “What do you get when you cross a mentally-ill loner with a system that abandons him and treats him like trash?” he asks — but the narrative doesn’t really dive deeper into the systemic issues perpetuating this. While the antagonists are the elite and privileged, Fleck’s relationship with the working class people around him are still held at distance. There is an interesting pattern of these interactions occurring specifically with Black women, like his therapist who attempts to relate to him, telling him “they don't give a shit about people like you, Arthur. And, they really don't really give a shit about people like me either,” after the city cuts funding for the program. However, Arthur barely seems to register this. He consistently feels that he isn’t seen by the people in his life, but there’s no recognition that this woman could be someone with shared experiences, rather than just being part of a hurtful system. Later, Joker presumably kills a different psychiatrist after telling her she wouldn’t get his joke, an intentional call back (through set design and casting) to his refusal to relate to the Black women trying to help him. If there is a message about shared class struggles, it doesn’t seem pushed by the narrative. Rather, Joker’s fight against “The System” supersedes any other understanding of intersectional inequality. Whether they’re seen as sympathetic or “ oppositional or antagonistic” towards Arthur, the lack of connection between Arthur and the Black women around him goes both ways. The two Black women I’ve mentioned are named only by their roles in institutions Arthur doesn’t feel supported by: social work and psychology. We see the city through Fleck’s eyes, and he never sees them as people. This is most prominent with his love interest and neighbor, Sophie. Even if reviews note that the other Black women in the film are unnamed, there is a consistent blind spot towards the fact Sophie is never named in the film. The only reason we know her name is from the credits and press tours. This could be an intentional clue that their relationship is a fantasy Arthur constructs. In his head, she has no hesitations, no other obligations, and no daughter. She is a blank slate who smiles beautifully and tells Arthur what he wants to hear, and he might not even know her name. But if it’s a clue, it’s not made up for later. We get very little of her as a real person, and even after the illusion falls away we stay on Arthur and leave the unnamed Sophie behind, sitting with Fleck’s loneliness after the loss of his fantasy without facing the dehumanization and discomfort for Sophie at being the subject of it. Arthur Fleck might start a movement against the white, rich elite of Joker’s Gotham, but the movie makes it clear that his revolution is also a white boys club.

_150CharacterPullQuoteFromBlurb: I find it so odd that a villain origin story from Hollywood is like a never-ending Russian doll. Now, instead of the Joker being the true villain, we can blame his mother!
copyEditedBlurb: This was so bad. I was only able to get through it at 2x speed. All the diversity stuff aside, this film was just bad. The pacing, the too-long shots, the tortoise timing of it all. It was like watching paint dry. Although, the scene where he gets his lick back on the rich white boys was engaging and interesting. Neal Curtis excellently explores the misogyny and misogynoir of the film in Ceasefire Magazine. The film uses women as props, never naming them on screen or giving them full stories. The only named woman is his mother, Penny Fleck, and she is shown to be the root of his problems. We never explore her mental health, like do with the Joker’s. I find it so odd that a villain origin story from Hollywood is like a never-ending Russian doll. Now, instead of the Joker being the true villain, we can blame his mother! Or his father if they gave Penny any grace on screen, and then some other thing, instead of directly citing capitalism and colonialism outright. Films exploring the shortcomings of mental health infrastructures, class systems, and social relations without containing social theory and history end up seeming incredibly narrow and lacking substance (because well, they are). Dr. Zuleyka Zevallos perfectly details the sociological harms the film perpetuates in her blog. Also, the group of random brown skinned teenagers who beat up the Joker is an interesting choice of casting and framing compared to the group of bougie white boys who antagonize him later. An imagined world where white boys don't commit street violence and rich snobs can’t be brown. But to be honest, the white boys were the ones brutally murdered on screen, and I’m glad it wasn’t the kids of color because that would have been worse. Still, interesting dynamics between the two groups of boys. The cops shooting the wrong person then getting jumped was odd framing to evoke cop sympathy. Real life cops are not like that; tragically, they are worse. The Joker’s dance was funny so I’ll give them that. There are some accurate depictions of what state-funded mental health services look like and I wish the film used this as a call-to-action to fix the system, rather than a prop piece to explain the Joker’s rage.
